Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The influence of the social environment on the infant skin microbiome

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The skin microbiome — the collection of microorganisms that live on the surface of the human body — plays a critical role in regulating the immune system, yet little is known about how infants first acquire skin microbes in early life. Since microbes are transmitted between people, and human infancy is highly social, interactions with caregivers may be a critical component of infant skin microbiome development. This doctoral dissertation project examines how infant social networks and specific interactions between infants and their caregivers influence the diversity of microbes living on infants’ skin. Results of this project shed light on the understudied relationship between social behaviors and the infant skin microbiome, as well as laying the foundation for future studies that connect early life microbial exposures to particular physiological outcomes. Study participants, including mothers and other caregivers, will receive personalized reports based on research results, including information about their social networks as well as the structure of their skin microbiome and how it compares to that of their infant. This project also contributes to enhancing diversity and inclusion by training undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in STEM research in skin microbiome laboratory methods and statistical analyses. The project also has public health translational potential with respect to infant wellbeing.<br/><br/>Unlike other great apes, human mothers rely on additional caregivers, such as grandparents and older siblings, for long-term assistance with infant care. Common infant care practices, including holding and carrying, promote direct skin-to-skin contact between caregivers and infants, suggesting opportunities for skin microbes to be shared with infants. This project will investigate how social caregiving influences the infant skin microbiome, with an emphasis on the microbial similarity between the skin of infants and their caregivers. Researchers will collect skin swab samples from infants, mothers, and additional caregivers, and use microbial gene sequencing to characterize and compare the skin microbes present in the samples. Caregivers will complete questionnaires that ask about the frequency of specific practices that put them in physical contact with infants. The researchers will use these data to generate social networks that describe social relationships between infants and their caregivers, suggesting potential routes through which skin microbes are shared with infants. This project offers a novel perspective on the benefits of social caregiving to infants, and the results will highlight the role that the social environment plays in linking early life microbial exposures to health outcomes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project information and outcomes

Human infancy is a highly social period during which mothers rely on assistance from alloparents (i.e. additional caregivers, such as older siblings or grandparents). Alloparents often provide direct care (i.e. allocare) to infants through physical contact, including through holding, carrying, and feeding. Since the skin microbiome (the collection of bacteria living on the skin) is altered by contact with other people, it is likely that common alloparental behaviors promote the transfer of bacteria from alloparents to infants. By combining biological samples with extensive questionnaire data, this project investigated how allocare influences the infant skin microbiome, with an emphasis on bacterial similarities between infants and their caregivers that may indicate pathways of bacterial sharing. This project generated novel data on the skin microbiome of infants and their caregivers. We applied both traditional and newer genetic sequencing technology to characterize the types of bacteria that are found on different skin sites. In addition to collecting microbiome samples from infants and their caregivers, we also administered a detailed questionnaire to mothers. This provided a rich understanding of infants' social environments, including their interactions with different caregivers. In addition, this project also provided training opportunities to five undergraduate students and one postbaccalaureate research technician. These trainees gained skills in microbiome sample collection, laboratory techniques, bioinformatics and statistics, data analysis, and the writing of scientific publications. The results of this study have been presented at scientific conferences and are being prepared for publication in academic journals.

Results

Our results show that the infant skin microbiome varied based on the social environment. On average, the armpit microbiome of infants who received allocare harbored more types of bacteria than did the armpit microbiome of their counterparts who did not receive allocare (Figure 1). In contrast, the hand microbiome of infants who received allocare contained fewer types of bacteria, compared to the hand microbiome of infants without alloparents (Figure 1). Bacterial diversity varied across the three infant skin sites in relation to the age and sex of their alloparents, as well as the type of allocare behavior received.

Using a statistical test that compares the composition of the microbiome between people, we found that the skin microbiome of infants who receive allocare was more distinct from the skin microbiome of their mothers (compared to infants who did not receive allocare). This pattern varied across the different skin sites that we profiled. For example, differences in bacterial composition were the greatest when we compared the skin microbiomes of (i) infants who received allocare and (ii) their mothers' hands (Figure 2). We saw similar patterns when we compared the skin microbiome of infants and their fathers; infants with alloparents showed greater distinction from the skin microbiomes of their fathers. These findings support the idea that allocare is associated with greater dissimilarity between the skin microbiomes of infants and their parents, and that this dissimilarity may be influenced by the additional bacterial exposures that infants receive from contact with their alloparents.

Our results also show that infant-mother bacterial sharing may vary based on the presence of alloparents. The data indicate that infants and mothers who receive alloparental support share more types of bacteria with each other (compared to infants and mothers who do not receive alloparental support). We found this pattern across all three infant skin sites. Originally, we predicted that infants who receive allocare would share fewer types of bacteria with their mothers, since they may be receiving more, or different kinds of, bacteria directly from their alloparents. Instead, our results suggest that infants may acquire bacteria from their alloparents and subsequently share those bacteria with their mothers.

Conclusions

Taken together, our results revealed associations between infants' social environments and the diversity and composition of their skin microbiomes. This study provides initial evidence that caregiving practices can contribute to the development of the infant skin microbiome. Since cultural and socioeconomic forces often shape infant caregiving practices (e.g. gender norms surrounding caregiving, or parental leave from the workplace), and the microbiome directly influences the immune system in early life, the microbiome serves as an intermediary between the social environment and human biology. Our study highlights how microbiome science can be leveraged as a tool for exploring how the social environment impacts the biology of human infancy.
